CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE FEDERAL CIRCUIT
No. 93-1128. Argued October 31
Mter respondent veteran had back surgery in a Department of Veterans Affairs facility for a condition unrelated to his military service
column2: he developed pain and weakness in his left leg
column3: which he alleged was the result of the surgery. He claimed disability benefits under 38 U. S. C.  1151
column4: which requires the VA to compensate for ""an injury
column5: or an aggravation of an injury
column6: that occurs ""as the result of"" VA treatment. The VA and the Board of Veterans' Appeals denied the claim on the ground that  1151
column7: as interpreted by 38 CFR  3.358(c)(3)
column8: only covers an injury if it resulted from negligent treatment by the VA or an accident occurring during treatment. The Court of Veterans Appeals reversed
column9: holding that  1151 neither imposes nor authorizes adoption of  3.358(c)(3)'s fault-or-accident requirement. The Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit affirmed.

column1: Held: Section 3.358(c)(3) is not consistent with the plain language of  1151

column3: or
column5: that the post-1934 legislative silence serves as an implicit endorsement of the fault-based policy; and that the policy deserves judicial deference due to its undisturbed endurance. Pp. 117-122.

NEBRASKA DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE v.
LOEWENSTEIN
CERTIORARI TO THE SUPREME COURT OF NEBRASKA No. 93-823. Argued October 11
Respondent
column3: owns shares in mutual funds (Trusts) that earn some of their income by participating in ""repurchase agreements"" (repos) involving federal debt securities. In such a transaction
column4: the party holding the securities (Seller-Borrower) transfers them to the Trusts in return for a specified amount of cash. At a later date
column5: the Trusts deliver the securities back to the Seller-Borrower
column6: who credits to the Trusts an amount equal to the cash transfer plus interest at an agreed-upon rate that bears no relation to the yield on the underlying securities. Ultimately
column7: the Trusts' interest income is distributed to respondent in proportion to his shares in the Trusts. Mter petitioner issued a Revenue Ruling concluding that interest income from repos is subject to Nebraska's income tax
column8: respondent brought this declaratory judgment action in state court
column9: asking that the Revenue Ruling be declared invalid as contrary to the Supremacy Clause and to 31 U. S. C.  3124(a)
column12: exempts from state taxation interest on ""obligations of the United States Government."" The court granted the relief
column13: and the Nebraska Supreme Court affirmed.

column1: Held:
1. Nebraska's taxation of the income respondent derived from the repos does not violate 3124(a). Pp.128-135.
(a) For purposes of  3124(a)
column2: the interest income earned by the Trusts is interest on loans from the Trusts to the Seller-Borrower
column3: not interest on federal securities; in this context
column4: the securities are merely collateral for these loans. Several features of the repos lead to this conclusion: (1) at a repo's commencement
column5: the Trusts pay the SellerBorrower a fixed sum of money
column6: which is repaid with interest at a rate bearing no relation to either the coupon interest paid or discount interest accrued on the federal securities during the term of the repo; (2) the Trusts may liquidate the securities should the Seller-Borrower default on the debt
column7: but
column9: they must pay to the Seller-Borrower any proceeds in excess of the amount of the debt plus expenses
column10: and may recover any deficiency from the Seller-Borrower; (3) the market value of the securities must be maintained at 102% of the original payment amount
column11: with the Seller-Borrower delivering cash or additional securities if the value falls below 102%

column1: ties if the value exceeds 102%; and (4) the Seller-Borrower may
column2: during the term of the repo
column3: substitute federal securities of equal market value for the securities initially involved in the transaction. The fact that the Trusts take ""delivery"" of the federal securities at the repo's commencement also is consistent with understanding the repos as loans
column4: since ""delivery"" perfects the Trusts' security interests in their collateral. Pp. 128-133.

column1: (b) Respondent's two objections to this interpretation of  3124(a) are unpersuasive. It does not matter that the Trusts and SellerBorrower characterize the repos as sales and repurchases
column2: since the substance and economic realities of the transactions show that the Trusts receive interest on cash they have lent to the Seller-Borrower. Cf. Frank Lyon Co. v. United States
column5: contrary to respondent's argument
column6: this case does not involve the construction or validity of the Nebraska income tax statute's add-back rule. Pp. 133-135.

column1: 2. Nebraska's taxation of income from repos involving federal securities does not violate the Supremacy Clause. Respondent has pointed to no statute
column3: or other manifestation of Nebraska policy that treats ""state"" repos differently from ""federal"" repos for tax purposes. Nor does the taxation at issue make it more difficult and expensive for the Federal Government to finance the national debt. Expert testimony referred to by respondent has no relevance to this case
column4: and respondent has shown no ""obvious and appreciable"" injury to the Government's borrowing power as a result of Nebraska's taxation of the Trusts' repo income
column5: see Rockford Life Ins. Co. v. Illinois Dept. of Revenue

column3: reversed and remanded.

Syllabus
FEDERAL ELECTION COMMISSION v. NRA POLITICAL VICTORY FUND ET AL.
CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA CIRCUIT
No.93-1151. Argued October 11

Petitioner Federal Election Commission (FEC) brought this civil action against respondents seeking to enforce a provision of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 (FECA). The District Court ruled against respondents. The Court of Appeals reversed and entered its judgment on October 22
column2: 1993. Without first seeking or obtaining the Solicitor General's authorization
column3: the FEC filed in its own name a petition for a writ of certiorari on January 18
column5: two days before the expiration of the 90-day filing period mandated by 28 U. S. C.  2101(c). The United States filed a brief contending that the FEC lacked statutory authority to represent itself in this case in this Court
column6: but that
column7: pursuant to 28 U. S. C.  518(a) and its implementing regulation
column8: the Solicitor General had authorized the FEC's petition by letter dated May 26
column9: 1994. This authorization came more than 120 days after the  2101(c) filing deadline had passed. The FEC filed a brief in response asserting that it has independent statutory authority to represent itself in this Court.

column1: Held:

1. The FEC may not independently file a petition for certiorari in this Court under 2 U. S. C. 437d(a)(6). That statute empowers the FEC ""to ... appeal any civil action ... to enforce the provisions of [the FECA]
column2: but it omits any mention of authority to file a ""petition for a writ of certiorari"" or otherwise conduct litigation before the Supreme Court. By contrast
column3: 26 U. S. C.  9010(d) and 9040(d) explicitly authorize the FEC to ""appeal from
column4: and to petition the Supreme Court for certiorari to review"" (emphasis added)
column5: judgments in actions to enforce the Presidential election fund laws
column6: thereby indicating a congressional intent to restrict the FEC's independent litigating authority in this Court to such actions. The contrasting language in  9040(d) and 437d(a)(6) is particularly telling because these sections were originally enacted as part of the same legislation. The mere existence of sound policy reasons for providing the FEC with independent litigating authority in this Court for actions enforcing the FECA does not demonstrate a congressional intent to alter the Solicitor General's prerogative under  518(a) to conduct and argue the Federal Government's litigation

column1: here
column2: since that statutory authority itself represents a policy choice by Congress. Nor is it dispositive that the FEC has represented itself before this Court in several FECA enforcement cases in the past
column3: since none of those cases involved a challenge to the Court's jurisdiction. Moreover
column4: the provisions authorizing the FEC to litigate in the federal courts are not the sort of substantive provisions which can be said to be within the agency's province to interpret. Pp. 90-97.

column1: 2. The Solicitor General's ""after-the-fact"" authorization does not relate back to the date of the FEC's unauthorized filing so as to make it timely. Under governing agency law principles
column3: the authorization simply came too late in the day to be effective: The Solicitor General attempted to ratify the FEC's filing on May 26
column5: but he could not himself have filed a certiorari petition on that date because the 90-day time period for filing a petition had already expired. This result is entirely consistent with
column6: and perhaps required by
column7: 2101(c). If the Solicitor General were allowed to retroactively authorize untimely agency petitions
column8: he would have the unilateral power to extend the 90-day statutory period by days
column12: even months. This would impermissibly blur  2101(c)'s jurisdictional deadline. pp. 98-99.

column1: Certiorari dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Reported below: 6 F.3d 821.
REHNQUIST

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE SUPREME COURT OF GEORGIA No. 93-908. Argued October 11
Georgia taxed retirement benefits paid by the Federal Government
column2: but exempted those paid by the State
column3: until this Court held
column5: that such a scheme violates the Federal Constitution. Georgia then repealed its state retiree tax exemption
column6: but did not offer federal retirees refunds for the unconstitutional taxes they had paid before the Court's 1989 decision. Petitioner Reich
column7: a federal retiree
column8: sought redress under a Georgia statute requiring refunds of ""illegally assessed"" taxes. In affirming the state trial court's denial of such relief
column9: the State Supreme Court held that the refund statute does not apply where the law under which the taxes were assessed and collected was itself subsequently declared to be invalid. It then denied Reich's petition seeking reconsideration under McKesson Corp. v. Division of Alcoholic Beverages and Tobacco
column13: which establish that due process requires a ""clear and certain"" remedy for taxes collected in violation of federal law
column14: and that a State may provide that remedy before the disputed taxes are paid (predeprivation)
column16: or both. Reich petitioned for certiorari
column17: and this Court remanded for further consideration in light of Harper v. Virginia Dept. of Taxation
column19: which had relied on McKesson in circumstances similar to this case. In again denying Reich's refund claim
column20: the State Supreme Court reviewed Georgia's predeprivation remedies and found those remedies to be ""ample.""

column1: Held: The Georgia Supreme Court erred in relying on Georgia's predeprivation remedies to deny relief. Although due process
column3: allows a State to maintain a remedial scheme that is exclusively pre deprivation
column5: or a hybrid
column6: and to reconfigure its scheme over time to fit changing needs
column7: it may not do what Georgia did here: ""bait and switch"" by reconfiguring
column10: Georgia held out what plainly appeared to be a ""clear and certain"" postdeprivation remedy
column13: only after Reich and others had paid the disputed taxes
column14: that no such remedy exists. In this regard
column15: the State Supreme Court's reliance on predeprivation procedures was entirely beside the point (and thus error)
column16: because even assuming the constitutional adequacy of those procedures-an issue not here addressed-no reasonable taxpayer

column1: would have thought that they represented
column2: in light of the apparent applicability of the refund statute
column3: the exclusive remedy for unlawful taxes. Cf. NAACP v. Alabama ex rel. Patterson
column4: 357 U. S. 449. The case is remanded for the provision of meaningful backward-looking relief consistent with due process and the McKesson line of cases. Pp. 110-114.

column3: reversed and remanded.

column10: Georgia held out what plainly appeared to be a ""clear and certain"" postdeprivation remedy

CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE THIRD CIRCUIT
No. 93-1197. Argued October 3
Petitioners
column3: were injured in unrelated incidents while employed by respondent bistate railway
column4: the Port Authority Trans-Hudson Corporation (PATH). PATH is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey (Port Authority or Authority)
column5: an entity created when Congress
column6: pursuant to the Constitution's Interstate Compact Clause
column7: consented to a compact between the Authority's parent States. Petitioners filed separate personal injury actions under the Federal Employers' Liability Act (FE LA). The District Court dismissed the suits under Third Circuit precedent
column9: Inc. v. Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
column11: which declared PATH a state agency entitled to Eleventh Amendment immunity from suit in federal court. The Third Circuit consolidated the cases and summarily affirmed. That court's assessment of PATH's immunity conflicts with the Second Circuit's decision in Feeney v. Port Authority Trans-Hudson Corporation

column1: Held: PATH is not entitled to Eleventh Amendment immunity from suit in federal court. Pp. 39-53.

(a) The Court presumes that an entity created pursuant to the Compact Clause does not qualify for Eleventh Amendment immunity unless there is good reason to believe that the States structured the entity to arm it with the States' own immunity
column2: and that Congress concurred in that purpose. Lake Country Estates
column3: Inc. v. Tahoe Regional Planning Agency
column5: 401. The Port Authority emphasizes that certain indicators of immunity are present in this case
column6: particularly provisions in the interstate compact and its implementing legislation establishing state control over Authority commissioners
column7: acts
column10: and state-court decisions typing the Authority as an agency of its parent States. Other indicators
column13: particularly the States' lack of financial responsibility for the Authority. Pp. 39-46.

column1: (b) When indicators of immunity point in different directions
column2: the Court is guided primarily by the Eleventh Amendment's twin reasons

column1: for being: the States' dignity and their financial solvency. Neither is implicated here. First
column2: there is no genuine threat to the dignity of New York or New Jersey in allowing petitioners to pursue FELA claims against PATH in federal court. The Port Authority is a discrete entity created by compact among three sovereigns
column3: the two States and the Federal Government. Federal courts are not alien to such an entity
column4: for they are ordained by one of its founders. Nor is it disrespectful to one State to call upon the entity to answer complaints in federal court
column5: for the States agreed to the power sharing
column6: coordination
column7: and unified action that typify Compact Clause creations. Second
column8: most Federal Courts of Appeals have identified the ""state treasury"" criterion-whether a judgment against the entity must be satisfied out of a State's treasury-as the most important consideration in determining whether a state-created entity qualifies for Eleventh Amendment immunity. The Port Authority
column10: is financially self-sufficient: it generates its own revenues and pays its own debts. Where
column12: the States are neither legally nor practically obligated to pay the entity's debts
column13: the Eleventh Amendment's core concern is not implicated. pp.47-51.

column1: (c) The conflict between the Second and Third Circuits no longer concerns the correct legal theory
column3: as shown in two post-Port Authority PEA decisions
column4: now accepts the prevailing ""state treasury"" view. A narrow intercircuit split persists only because the Circuits differ on whether the Port Authority's debts are those of its parent States. In resolving that issue
column5: the Port Authority PEA court relied primarily on a compact provision calling for modest state contributions
column6: capped at $100
column7: 000 annually from each State
column8: unless Port Authority revenues were ""adequate to meet all expenditures
column9: but the court drew from that provision far more than its text warrants. pp.51-52.

u. S. BANCORP MORTGAGE CO. v. BONNER MALL PARTNERSHIP
CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE NINTH CIRCUIT
No. 93-714. Argued October 4
Mter this Court granted the petition for a writ of certiorari and received briefing on the merits
column2: the parties entered into a settlement and agreed that the case was thereby mooted. Petitioner
column3: however
column4: also requested that the Court exercise its power under 28 U. S. C.  2106 to vacate the judgment of the Court of Appeals. Respondent opposed the motion.

column1: Held:
1. This Court does not lack the power to entertain petitioner's motion to vacate. Section 2106 supplies the vacatur power
column2: and respondent's suggestion is rejected that Article Ill's case or controversy requirement prohibits the exercise of that power when no live dispute exists due to a settlement that has mooted the case. Although Article III prevents the Court from considering the merits of a judgment that has become moot while awaiting review
column3: the Court may nevertheless make such disposition of the whole case as justice may require. Walling v. James V. Reuter

column1: 2. Mootness by reason of settlement does not justify vacatur of a federal civil judgment under review. United States v. Munsingwear
column5: and subsequent cases distinguished. Equitable principles have always been implicit in this Court's exercise of the vacatur power
column6: and the principal equitable factor to which the Court has looked is whether the party seeking vacatur caused the mootness by voluntary action. Where mootness results from settlement
column7: the losing party has voluntarily forfeited his legal remedy by the ordinary processes of appeal or certiorari
column8: thereby surrendering his claim to the extraordinary equitable remedy of vacatur. It is irrelevant that the party who won below also agreed to the settlement
column9: since it is the losing party who has the burden of demonstrating equitable entitlement to vacatur. This result is supported by the public interest in the orderly operation of the federal judicial system; petitioner's countervailing policy arguments are not persuasive. Although exceptional circumstances may conceivably justify vacatur when mootness results from settlement
column10: such circumstances do not include the mere fact that the settlement agreement provides for vacatur. Pp. 22-29.

column1: Motion to vacate denied and case dismissed as moot. Reported below: 2 F.3d 899.

column1: JUSTICE SCALIA delivered the opinion of the Court.
The question in this case is whether appellate courts in the federal system should vacate civil judgments of subordinate courts in cases that are settled after appeal is filed or certiorari sought.
I

column2: Northtown Investments built the Bonner Mall in Bonner County
column3: Idaho
column4: with financing from a bank in that State. In 1986
column5: respondent Bonner Mall Partnership (Bonner) acquired the mall
column6: while petitioner U. S. Bancorp Mortgage Co. (Bancorp) acquired the loan and mortgage from the Idaho bank. In 1990

column4: also requested that the Court exercise its power under 28 U. S. C.  2106 to vacate the judgment of the Court of Appeals. Respondent opposed the motion.

column1: Held:
1. This Court does not lack the power to entertain petitioner's motion to vacate. Section 2106 supplies the vacatur power
column2: and respondent's suggestion is rejected that Article Ill's case or controversy requirement prohibits the exercise of that power when no live dispute exists due to a settlement that has mooted the case. Although Article III prevents the Court from considering the merits of a judgment that has become moot while awaiting review
column3: the Court may nevertheless make such disposition of the whole case as justice may require. Walling v. James V. Reuter

column1: 2. Mootness by reason of settlement does not justify vacatur of a federal civil judgment under review. United States v. Munsingwear
column5: and subsequent cases distinguished. Equitable principles have always been implicit in this Court's exercise of the vacatur power
column6: and the principal equitable factor to which the Court has looked is whether the party seeking vacatur caused the mootness by voluntary action. Where mootness results from settlement
column7: the losing party has voluntarily forfeited his legal remedy by the ordinary processes of appeal or certiorari
column8: thereby surrendering his claim to the extraordinary equitable remedy of vacatur. It is irrelevant that the party who won below also agreed to the settlement
column9: since it is the losing party who has the burden of demonstrating equitable entitlement to vacatur. This result is supported by the public interest in the orderly operation of the federal judicial system; petitioner's countervailing policy arguments are not persuasive. Although exceptional circumstances may conceivably justify vacatur when mootness results from settlement
column10: such circumstances do not include the mere fact that the settlement agreement provides for vacatur. Pp. 22-29.

column1: Held: A capital defendant need not file a formal habeas corpus petition in order to invoke his right to counsel under  848(q)(4)(B) and to establish a federal court's jurisdiction to enter a stay of execution. Pp. 854-859.
(a) The language and purposes of 848(q)(4)(B) and its related provisions establish that the right to qualified appointed counsel adheres before the filing of a formal
column2: legally sufficient habeas petition and includes a right to legal assistance in the preparation of such a petition. Thus
column3: a ""post conviction proceeding"" within 848(q)(4)(B)'s meaning is commenced by the filing of a death row defendant's motion requesting the appointment of counsel for his federal habeas proceeding. McFarland filed such a motion and was entitled to the appointment of a lawyer. Pp.854-857.

column1: (b) The District Court had jurisdiction to grant McFarland's motion for stay of execution. The language of 848(q)(4)(B) and 2251 indicates that ""post conviction"" and ""habeas corpus"" refer to the same proceeding. Thus

column3: ET AL. v.

column1: DE GRANDY ET AL.
APPEAL FROM THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF FLORIDA
No. 92-519. Argued October 4
In these consolidated cases
column3: a group of black voters
column4: and the Federal Government claim that Florida's reapportionment plan for the State's single-member Senate and House districts (SJR 2-G) unlawfully dilutes the voting strength of Hispanics and blacks in the Dade County area
column5: in violation of  2 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965. The State Supreme Court
column6: in a review required by the State Constitution
column7: declared the plan valid under federal and state law
column8: while acknowledging that time constraints precluded full review and authorizing any interested party to bring a  2 challenge in that court. The plaintiffs chose
column10: to pursue their claims in federal court. A three-judge District Court reviewed the totality of circumstances as required by 2 and Thornburg v. Gingles
column12: and concluded that the three Gingles preconditions for establishing dilution were satisfied
column13: justifying a finding of vote dilution. Specifically
column14: the court found that voting proceeded largely along racial lines
column15: producing a system of ""tripartite politics""; that Hispanics in the Dade County area could constitute a majority in 11 House and 4 Senate districts
column16: but that SJR 2-G had created only 9 House and 3 Senate districts with Hispanic majorities; that an additional majority-black Senate district could have been drawn; and that Florida's minorities had suffered historically from official discrimination
column19: and political effects of which they continued to feel. The court imposed a remedial plan with 11 majority-Hispanic House districts but
column20: concluding that the remedies for blacks and Hispanics in the senatorial districts were mutually exclusive
column21: left SJR 2-G's Senate districts in force.

column1: Held:
1. The District Court properly refused to give preclusive effect to the State Supreme Court's decision validating SJR 2-G. Pp. 1004-1006.
*Together with No. 92-593
column2: De Grandy et al. v. Johnson
column3: Speaker of the Florida House of Representatives
column5: and No. 92-767
column6: United States v. Florida
column7: also on appeal from the same court.

column1: Syllabus
2. There is no violation of  2 in SJR 2-G's House districts
column2: where in spite of continuing discrimination and racial bloc voting
column3: minority voters form effective voting majorities in a number of House districts roughly proportional to their respective shares in the voting-age population. While such proportionality is not dispositive
column4: it is a relevant fact in the totality of circumstances to be analyzed when determining whether minority voters have ""less opportunity than other members of the electorate to participate in the political process and to elect representatives of their choice

column1: (a) This Court assumes without deciding that the first Gingles factor has been satisfied in these cases. pp. 1008-1009.
(b) While proof of the Gingles factors is necessary to make out a claim that a set of district lines violates  2
column2: it is not necessarily sufficient. Rather
column3: a court must assess the probative significance of the Gingles factors after considering all circumstances with arguable bearing on the issue of equal political opportunity. Here
column4: the court misjudged the relative importance of the Gingles factors and of historical discrimination by equating dilution where these had been found with failure to maximize the number of majority-minority districts. Dilution cannot be inferred from the mere failure to guarantee minority voters maximum political influence. Pp. 1009-1017.

column1: (c) Ruling as the State proposes
column2: that as a matter of law no dilution occurs whenever proportionality exists
column3: would likewise provide a bright-line decisional rule only in derogation of the statutory text. While proportionality is an indication that minority voters have equal political and electoral opportunity in spite of racial polarization
column5: and it cannot serve as a shortcut to determining whether a set of districts unlawfully dilutes minority voting strength. Pp. 1017-1021.

column1: (d) This Court need not reach the United States' argument that proportionality should be assessed only on a statewide basis in cases challenging districts for electing a body with statewide jurisdiction. The argument would recast this litigation as it comes before the Court
column2: for up until now the dilution claims have been litigated not on a statewide basis
column3: but on a smaller geographical scale. Pp. 1021-1022.

column1: 3. The District Court's decision to leave undisturbed the State's plan for Senate districts was correct. However
column3: the court once again misapprehended the legal test for vote dilution. As in the case of the House districts
column4: the totality of circumstances appears not to support a finding of dilution in the Senate districts. pp. 1023-1024.

column2: affirmed in part and reversed in part.

WILLIAMSON v. UNITED STATES
CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE ELEVENTH CIRCUIT
No. 93-5256. Argued April 25
Mter Reginald Harris refused to testify at petitioner Williamson's federal trial on cocaine possession and distribution charges
column3: under Federal Rule of Evidence 804(b)(3)'s hearsay exception for statements against penal interest
column4: a Drug Enforcement Administration agent could recount two custodial interviews in which Harris had freely confessed to receiving and transporting the drugs in question
column5: but also implicated Williamson as the drugs' owner. Williamson was eventually convicted
column6: and the Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held: The judgment is vacated
column2: and the case is remanded. 981 F.2d 1262
column3: vacated and remanded.

column1: JUSTICE O'CONNOR delivered the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I
column3: and II-B

column1: 1. The most faithful reading of Rule 804(b)(3)-which renders admissible ""statement[s] which ... so far ten[d] to subject the declarant to ... criminal liability ... that a reasonable person ... would not have made [them] unless believing [them] to be true"" -is that it does not allow admission of non-self-inculpatory statements
column2: even if they are made within a broader narrative that is generally self-inculpatory. Although the statutory term ""statement"" can mean either an extended declaration or a single remark
column3: the principle behind the Rule
column4: so far as it is discernible from the text
column5: points clearly to the narrower reading
column6: so that only those remarks within a confession that are individually self-inculpatory are covered. The Rule is founded on the commonsense notion that reasonable people
column7: even those who are not especially honest
column8: tend not to make self-inculpatory statements unless they believe them to be true. This notion does not extend to a confession's non-self-inculpatory parts-to parts that are actually self-exculpatory
column10: even ones that are neutral as to interest. A district court may not just assume that a statement is self-inculpatory because it is part of a fuller confession
column11: especially when the statement implicates someone else. The policy expressed in the Rule's text is clear enough that it outweighs whatever force lies in ambiguous statements contained in the Advisory Committee Notes to the Rule. Pp.598-602.

column1: 2. The foregoing reading does not eviscerate the against penal interest exception. There are many circumstances in which Rule 804(b)(3)
does allow the admission of statements that inculpate a criminal defendant. Even the confessions of arrested accomplices may be admissible if they are truly self-inculpatory
column2: rather than merely attempts to shift blame or curry favor. The question under the Rule is always whether the statement at issue was sufficiently against the declarant's penal interest under the Rule's language
column3: and this question can only be answered in light of all the surrounding circumstances. Pp. 602-604.

column1: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
column3: concluded in Part II -C that
column5: the Court of Appeals must inquire in the first instance whether each of the statements in Harris' confession was truly self-inculpatory. Pp. 604-605.

column3: ET AL. v. FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION ET AL.

column1: APPEAL FROM THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA
No. 93-44. Argued January 12

Concerned that a competitive imbalance between cable television and over-the-air broadcasters was endangering the broadcasters' ability to compete for a viewing audience and thus for necessary operating revenues
column2: Congress passed the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992. Sections 4 and 5 of the Act require cable television systems to devote a specified portion of their channels to the transmission of local commercial and public broadcast stations. Soon after the Act became law
column3: appellants
column5: challenged the constitutionality of the must-carry provisions. The District Court granted the United States and intervenordefendants summary judgment
column6: ruling that the provisions are consistent with the First Amendment. The court rejected appellants' argument that the provisions warrant strict scrutiny as a content-based regulation and sustained them under the intermediate standard of scrutiny set forth in United States v. O'Brien
column8: concluding that they are sufficiently tailored to serve the important governmental interest in the preservation of local broadcasting.

column1: Held: The judgment is vacated
column2: and the case is remanded. 819 F. Supp. 32
column3: vacated and remanded.

column1: JUSTICE KENNEDY delivered the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I
column3: and III -A
column4: concluding that the appropriate standard by which to evaluate the constitutionality of the must-carry provisions is the intermediate level of scrutiny applicable to content-neutral restrictions that impose an incidental burden on speech. Pp. 636-664.

column1: (a) Because the must-carry provisions impose special obligations upon cable operators and special burdens upon cable programmers
column2: heightened First Amendment scrutiny is demanded. The less rigorous standard of scrutiny now reserved for broadcast regulation
column3: see Red Lion Broadcasting Co. v. FCC
column5: should not be extended to cable regulation
column6: since the rationale for such review-the dual problems of spectrum scarcity and signal interference-does not apply in the context of cable. Nor is the mere assertion of dysfunction or failure in the cable market
column7: without more
column8: sufficient to shield a speech regulation from the First Amendment standards applicable to nonbroadcast media.

column1: Moreover
column2: while enforcement of a generally applicable law against members of the press may sometimes warrant only rational-basis scrutiny
column3: laws that single out the press for special treatment pose a particular danger of abuse by the State and are always subject to some degree of heightened scrutiny. Pp. 636-641.

column1: (b) The must-carry rules are content neutral
column2: and thus are not subject to strict scrutiny. They are neutral on their face because they distinguish between speakers in the television programming market based only upon the manner in which programmers transmit their messages to viewers
column3: not the messages they carry. The purposes underlying the must-carry rules are also unrelated to content. Congress' overriding objective was not to favor programming of a particular content
column4: but rather to preserve access to free television programming for the 40 percent of Americans without cable. The challenged provisions' design and operation confirm this purpose. Congress' acknowledgment that broadcast television stations make a valuable contribution to the Nation's communications structure does not indicate that Congress regarded broadcast programming to be more valuable than cable programming; rather
column5: it reflects only the recognition that the services provided by broadcast television have some intrinsic value and are worth preserving against the threats posed by cable. It is also incorrect to suggest that Congress enacted must-carry in an effort to exercise content control over what subscribers view on cable television
column6: given the minimal extent to which the Federal Communications Commission and Congress influence the programming offered by broadcast stations. Pp. 641-652.

column1: (c) None of appellants' additional arguments suffices to require strict scrutiny in this case. The provisions do not intrude on the editorial control of cable operators. They are content neutral in application
column2: and they do not force cable operators to alter their own messages to respond to the broadcast programming they must carry. In addition
column3: the physical connection between the television set and the cable network gives cable operators bottleneck
column5: control over most programming delivered into subscribers' homes. Miami Herald Publishing Go. v. Tornillo
column7: and Pacific Gas & Elec. Go. v. Public Util. Gomm'n of Gal.
column9: distinguished. Strict scrutiny is also not triggered by Congress' preference for broadcasters over cable operators
column10: since it is based not on the content of the programming each group offers
column11: but on the belief that broadcast television is in economic peril. Nor is such scrutiny warranted by the fact that the provisions single out certain members of the press-here
column12: cable operators-for disfavored treatment. Such differential treatment is justified by the special characteristics of the cable medium-namely

Syllabus
DOLAN v. CITY OF TIGARD
CERTIORARI TO THE SUPREME COURT OF OREGON No. 93-518. Argued March 23

The City Planning Commission of respondent city conditioned approval of petitioner Dolan's application to expand her store and pave her parking lot upon her compliance with dedication ofland (1) for a public greenway along Fanno Creek to minimize flooding that would be exacerbated by the increases in impervious surfaces associated with her development and (2) for a pedestrian/bicycle pathway intended to relieve traffic congestion in the city's Central Business District. She appealed the commission's denial of her request for variances from these standards to the Land Use Board of Appeals (L UBA)
column2: alleging that the land dedication requirements were not related to the proposed development and therefore constituted an uncompensated taking of her property under the Fifth Amendment. LUBA found a reasonable relationship between (1) the development and the requirement to dedicate land for a greenway
column3: since the larger building and paved lot would increase the impervious surfaces and thus the runoff into the creek
column4: and (2) alleviating the impact of increased traffic from the development and facilitating the provision of a pathway as an alternative means of transportation. Both the Oregon Court of Appeals and the Oregon Supreme Court affirmed.

column1: Held: The city's dedication requirements constitute an uncompensated taking of property. Pp. 383-396.
(a) Under the well-settled doctrine of ""unconstitutional conditions
column2: the government may not require a person to give up a constitutional right in exchange for a discretionary benefit conferred by the government where the property sought has little or no relationship to the benefit. In evaluating Dolan's claim
column3: it must be determined whether an ""essential nexus"" exists between a legitimate state interest and the permit condition. Nollan v. California Coastal Comm'n
column5: 837. If one does
column6: then it must be decided whether the degree of the exactions demanded by the permit conditions bears the required relationship to the projected impact of the proposed development. Id.

column1: (b) Preventing flooding along Fanno Creek and reducing traffic congestion in the district are legitimate public purposes; and a nexus exists between the first purpose and limiting development within the creek's
floodplain and between the second purpose and providing for alternative means of transportation. Pp. 386-388.

(c) In deciding the second question-whether the city's findings are constitutionally sufficient to justify the conditions imposed on Dolan's permit-the necessary connection required by the Fifth Amendment is ""rough proportionality."" No precise mathematical calculation is required
column2: but the city must make some sort of individualized determination that the required dedication is related both in nature and extent to the proposed development's impact. This is essentially the ""reasonable relationship"" test adopted by the majority of the state courts. Pp.388-391.

column1: (d) The findings upon which the city relies do not show the required reasonable relationship between the floodplain easement and Dolan's proposed building. The Community Development Code already required that Dolan leave 15% of her property as open space
column2: and the undeveloped floodplain would have nearly satisfied that requirement. However
column3: the city has never said why a public
column5: greenway is required in the interest of flood control. The difference to Dolan is the loss of her ability to exclude others from her property
column6: yet the city has not attempted to make any individualized determination to support this part of its request. The city has also not met its burden of demonstrating that the additional number of vehicle and bicycle trips generated by Dolan's development reasonably relates to the city's requirement for a dedication of the pathway easement. The city must quantify its finding beyond a conclusory statement that the dedication could offset some of the traffic demand generated by the development. Pp. 392-396.

column3: reversed and remanded.

column4: an Oregon jury awarded Oberg $5 million in punitive damages
column5: over five times the amount of his compensatory damages award. In affirming
column6: both the State Court of Appeals and the State Supreme Court rejected Honda's argument that the punitive damages award violated due process because it was excessive and because Oregon courts have no power to correct excessive verdicts under a 1910 amendment to the State Constitution

Life Ins. Co. v. Has lip
column8: 499 U. S. 1. The court also declined to interpret Haslip to hold that due process requires the amount of a punitive damages award to be subject to postverdict or appellate review
column9: and noted that Oregon courts are not powerless because they may vacate a judgment if there is no evidence supporting the jury's decision

column1: Held: Oregon's denial of review of the size of punitive damages awards violates the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process Clause. Pp. 420-435.
(a) The Constitution imposes a substantive limit on the size of punitive damages awards. Pacific Mut. Life Ins. Co. v. Haslip
column2: 499 U. S. 1; TXO Production Corp. v. Alliance Resources Corp.
column3: 509 U. S. 443. The opinions in these cases strongly emphasized the importance of the procedural component of the Due Process Clause
column4: and suggest that the analysis here should focus on Oregon's departure from traditional procedures. Pp.420-421.

column1: (b) Judicial review of the size of punitive damages awards was a safeguard against excessive awards under the common law
column3: e. g.
column5: 3 F. Cas. 760
column7: and in modern practice in the federal courts and every State
column9: judges review the size of such awards. See
column11: Dagnello v. Long Island R. Co.

column1: Syllabus

(c) There is a dramatic difference between judicial review under the common law and the scope of review available in Oregon. At least since the State Supreme Court definitively construed the 1910 amendment in Van Lom v. Schneiderman
column4: Oregon law has provided no procedure for reducing or setting aside a punitive damages award where the only basis for relief is the amount awarded. No Oregon court for more than half a century has inferred passion or prejudice from the size of a damages award
column5: and no court in more than a decade has even hinted that it might possess the power to do so. If courts had such power
column6: the State Supreme Court would have mentioned it in responding to Honda's arguments in this very case. The review that is provided ensures only that there is evidence to support some punitive damages
column7: not that the evidence supports the amount actually awarded
column8: thus leaving the possibility that a guilty defendant may be unjustly punished. Pp. 426-429.

column1: (d) This Court has not hesitated to find proceedings violative of due process where a party has been deprived of a well-established commonlaw protection against arbitrary and inaccurate adjudication. See
column3: Tumey v. Ohio
column4: 273 U. S. 510. Punitive damages pose an acute danger of arbitrary deprivation of property
column5: since jury instructions typically leave the jury with wide discretion in choosing amounts and since evidence of a defendant's net worth creates the potential that juries will use their verdicts to express biases against big businesses. Oregon has removed one of the few procedural safeguards which the common law provided against that danger without providing any substitute procedure and without any indication that the danger has in any way subsided over time. Hurtado v. California
column7: 538; International Shoe Co. v. Washington

column1: (e) The safeguards that Oberg claims Oregon has provided-the limitation of punitive damages to the amount specified in the complaint
column2: the clear and convincing standard of proof
column3: preverdict determination of maximum allowable punitive damages
column4: and detailed jury instructionsdo not adequately safeguard against arbitrary awards. Nor does the fact that a jury's arbitrary decision to acquit a defendant charged with a crime is unreviewable offer a historic basis for such discretion in civil cases. The Due Process Clause says nothing about arbitrary grants of freedom
column5: but its whole purpose is to prevent arbitrary deprivations of liberty or property. Pp. 432-435.

In the Insanity Defense Reform Act of 1984 (IDRA or Act)
column2: Congress made insanity an affirmative defense
column3: created a special verdict of ""not guilty only by reason of insanity"" (NGI)
column4: and established a comprehensive civil commitment procedure. At his trial on a federal criminal charge
column5: petitioner Shannon raised the insanity defense and asked the District Court to instruct the jury that an NGI verdict would result in his involuntary commitment. The court refused
column6: and the jury returned a guilty verdict. In affirming
column7: the Court of Appeals noted that
column9: juries were not to be instructed concerning the consequences of an insanity acquittal. Because there was no directive in the IDRA to the contrary
column10: the court ""adhere[d] to the established axiom that it is inappropriate for a jury to consider or be informed about the consequences of its verdict.""

column1: Held: A federal district court is not required to instruct the jury regarding the consequences to the defendant of an NGI verdict. Pp.579-588.

(a) The principle that juries are not to consider the consequences of their verdicts is a reflection of the basic division of labor between the judge as sentencer and the jury as trier of fact. Providing jurors sentencing information invites them to ponder matters that are not within their province
column3: and creates a strong possibility of confusion. Pp. 579-580.

column1: (b) The IDRA does not require courts to depart from the foregoing principle. The text of the Act gives no indication that jurors are to be instructed regarding the consequences of an NGI verdict. The Court rejects Shannon's contention that Congress
column2: by modeling the IDRA on D. C. Code Ann.  24-301
column3: impliedly adopted a D. C. Circuit decision that endorsed the practice of giving the instruction in question in the context of  24-301. Because Congress departed from the scheme embodied in  24-301 in several significant ways when it passed the IDRA
column4: the canon of construction urged by Shannon-that adoption of the wording of a statute from another legislative jurisdiction carries with it the jurisdiction's judicial interpretations of that wording-is not applicable. The single passage in the legislative history endorsing the giving of the instruction in question is in no way anchored in the IDRA's text and is not entitled to authoritative weight. Pp. 580-584.

column1: Syllabus

(c) The instruction in question is not required as a matter of general federal criminal practice. Even if Shannon is correct that some jurors may harbor the mistaken belief that defendants found NGI will be released into society immediately
column2: it must be assumed that his jury followed its instructions to apply the law regardless of the consequences and not to consider or discuss punishment. See Richardson v. Marsh
column4: 206. Also unpersuasive is Shannon's contention that the instruction would allay the fears of such misinformed jurors. Indeed
column5: because the only mandatory period of confinement under the IDRA is a maximum of 40 days between an NGI verdict and a required commitment hearing
column6: an instruction of the type at issue might incline jurors to convict in order to eliminate the possibility that a dangerous defendant could be released after 40 days or less. In any event
column7: the instruction would draw the jury's attention to the very thing-the possible consequences of its verdict-that it should ignore. Moreover
column8: Shannon offers no principled way to limit the availability of such instructions to cases involving NGI verdicts
column9: as opposed to the many other aspects of the criminal sentencing process with which jurors may be unfamiliar. Given the comprehensive nature of Congress' review of the insanity defense during the enactment of the IDRA
column10: the Court will not invoke its supervisory powers to require an instruction that Congress chose not to mandate. Pp.584-587.

column1: (d) This decision should not be misunderstood as an absolute prohibition on instructing the jury with regard to the consequences of an NGI verdict. An instruction of some form may be necessary under certain limited circumstances to remedy a misstatement or error. That is not the case here
column3: for there is no indication that any improper statement was made in the presence of the jury during Shannon's trial. Pp. 587-588.

Syllabus
SIMMONS v. SOUTH CAROLINA
CERTIORARI TO THE SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA No. 92-9059. Argued January 18
During the penalty phase of petitioner's South Carolina trial
column2: the State argued that his future dangerousness was a factor for the jury to consider when deciding whether to sentence him to death or life imprisonment for the murder of an elderly woman. In rebuttal
column3: petitioner presented evidence that his future dangerousness was limited to elderly women and thus there was no reason to expect violent acts from him in prison. However
column4: the court refused to give the jury his proposed instruction that under state law he was ineligible for parole. When asked by the jury whether life imprisonment carried with it the possibility of parole
column5: the court instructed the jury not to consider parole in reaching its verdict and that the terms life imprisonment and death sentence were to be understood to have their plain and ordinary meaning. The jury returned a death sentence. On appeal
column6: the State Supreme Court concluded that regardless of whether a trial court's refusal to inform a sentencing jury about a defendant's parole ineligibility might ever be error
column7: the instruction given to petitioner's jury satisfied in substance his request for a charge on such ineligibility.

column1: Held: The judgment is reversed
column2: and the case is remanded. 310 S. C. 439

column1: JUSTICE BLACKMUN
column3: JUSTICE SOUTER
column5: concluded:

column1: 1. Where a defendant's future dangerousness is at issue
column2: and state law prohibits his release on parole
column3: due process requires that the sentencing jury be informed that the defendant is parole ineligible. An individual cannot be executed on the basis of information which he had no opportunity to deny or explain. Gardner v. Florida
column5: 362. Petitioner's jury reasonably may have believed that he could be released on parole if he were not executed. To the extent that this misunderstanding pervaded its deliberations
column6: it had the effect of creating a false choice between sentencing him to death and sentencing him to a limited period of incarceration. The trial court's refusal to apprise the jury of information so crucial to its determination
column7: particularly when the State alluded to the defendant's future dangerousness in its argument
column8: cannot be reconciled with this Court's well-established precedents interpreting the Due Process Clause. See

column1: 2. The trial court's instruction that life imprisonment was to be understood in its plain and ordinary meaning did not satisfy petitioner's request for a parole ineligibility charge
column2: since it did nothing to dispel the misunderstanding reasonable jurors may have about the way in which any particular State defines ""life imprisonment."" Pp. 169-171.

column1: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
column2: joined by THE CHIEF JUSTICE and JUSTICE KENNEDY
column3: concluded that where the State puts a defendant's future dangerousness in issue
column4: and the only available alternative sentence to death is life imprisonment without possibility of parole
column5: due process entitles the defendant to inform the sentencing jury-either by argument or instruction-that he is parole ineligible. If the prosecution does not argue future dangerousness
column6: a State may appropriately decide that parole is not a proper issue for the jury's consideration even if the only alternative sentence to death is life imprisonment without the possibility of parole. Here
column7: the trial court's instruction did not satisfy petitioner's request for a parole ineligibility charge
column8: since the rejection of parole is a recent development displacing the longstanding practice of parole availability
column9: and since common sense dictates that many jurors might not know whether a life sentence carries with it the possibility of parole. pp. 175-178.

column1: Held: The pricing order unconstitutionally discriminates against interstate commerce. Pp. 192-207.

(a) The order is clearly unconstitutional under this Court's decisions invalidating state laws designed to benefit local producers of goods by creating tariff-like barriers that neutralized the competitive and economic advantages possessed by lower cost out-of-state producers. See
column3: Bacchus Imports
column5: 468 U. S. 263. The ""premium payments"" are effectively a tax making milk produced out of State more expensive. Although that tax also applies to milk produced in Massachusetts
column6: its effect on Massachusetts producers is entirely (indeed more than) offset by the subsidy provided exclusively to Massachusetts dairy farmers
column7: who are thereby empowered to sell at or below the price charged by lower cost out-of-state producers. Pp. 192-197.

column1: (b) Respondent's principal argument-that
column2: because both the localsubsidy and nondiscriminatory-tax components of the order are valid
column3: the combination of the two is equally valid-is rejected. Even granting respondent's assertion that both components of the pricing order would be constitutional standing alone
column4: the order must still fall because it is funded principally from taxes on the sale of milk produced in other States and therefore burdens interstate commerce. More fundamentally
column5: the argument is logically flawed in its assumption that the lawfulness of each of two acts establishes the legality of their combination.

column1: Indeed
column2: by conjoining a tax and a subsidy
column3: Massachusetts has created a program more dangerous to interstate commerce than either part alone:

column1: The Commonwealth's political processes cannot be relied on to prevent legislative abuse where dairy farmers
column2: one of the powerful in-state interests that would ordinarily be expected to lobby against the order premium as a tax raising milk prices
column3: have been mollified by the subsidy. pp. 198-202.

column1: (c) Respondent's second argument-that the order is not discriminatory because the dealers who pay premiums are not competitors of the farmers who receive disbursements-cannot withstand scrutiny. The imposition of a differential burden on any part of the stream of commerce-from wholesaler to retailer to consumer-is invalid because a burden placed at any point will result in a disadvantage to the out-ofstate producer. pp. 202-203.
(d) If accepted
column2: respondent's third argument-that the order is not protectionist because the program's costs are borne only by Massachusetts dealers and consumers and its benefits are distributed exclusively to Massachusetts farmers-would undermine almost every discriminatory tax case. State taxes are ordinarily paid by in-state businesses and consumers
column3: yet if they discriminate against out-of-state products they are unconstitutional. More fundamentally
column4: the argument ignores the fact that Massachusetts dairy farmers are part of an integrated interstate market. The obvious impact of the order on out-of-state production demonstrates that it is simply wrong to assume that it burdens only in-state consumers and dealers. Pp. 203-204.

column1: (e) Acceptance of respondent's final argument-that the order's incidental burden on commerce is justified by the local benefit of saving the financially distressed dairy industry-would make a virtue of the vice that the rule against discrimination condemns. Preservation of local industry by protecting it from the rigors of interstate competition is the hallmark of the economic protectionism that the Commerce Clause prohibits. Pp. 204-207.

CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA CIRCUIT
No. 93-356. Argued March 21
Title 47 U. S. C.  203(a) requires communications common carriers to file tariffs with the Federal Communications Commission
column2: and  203(b)(2) authorizes the Commission to ""modify any requirement made by or under ... this section .... "" Relying on the latter provision
column3: the Commission issued an order determining that its earlier decision to make tariff filing optional for all nondominant long-distance carriers was within its authority to ""modify."" American Telephone and Telegraph Co.
column5: filed a motion with the Court of Appeals seeking summary reversal of the Commission's order. The motion was granted on the basis of that court's prior decision determining that the Commission's authorization of permissive detariffing violated  203(a).

column1: Held: The Commission's permissive detariffing policy is not a valid exercise of its  203(b)(2) authority to ""modify any requirement."" Because virtually every dictionary in use now and at the time the statute was enacted defines ""to modify"" as meaning to change moderately or in minor fashion
column2: the word ""modify"" must be seen to have a connotation of increment or limitation. That  203(b)(2) does not contemplate basic or fundamental changes is also demonstrated by the fact that the only exception to it deals with a very minor matter: The Commission may not require the period for giving notice of tariff changes to exceed 120 days. The Commission's permissive detariffing policy cannot be justified as a nonfundamental ""modification."" The tariff filing requirement is the heart of the common carrier subchapter of the Communications Act of 1934
column3: and the policy eliminates that requirement entirely for all except one firm in the long-distance sector
column4: and for 40% of all consumers in that sector. Moreover
column5: it is hard to imagine that a condition shared by so many affected parties qualifies as ""special"" under  203(b)(2)'s requirement that when the Commission proceeds ""by general order"" to make a modification
column6: the order can only apply ""to special circumstances or conditions."" The Commission's interpretation of the statute is there-

column1: *Together with No. 93-521
column2: United States et al. v. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. et al.
column3: also on certiorari to the same court.

column1: fore not entitled to deference
column2: since it goes beyond the meaning that the statute can bear. That Congress seemed to manifest agreement with the parties' respective interpretations in later legislation is irrelevant; there has been no consistent history of legislation to which one or the other interpretation is essential. Finally
column3: petitioners' argument that their interpretation better serves the Act's broad purpose of promoting efficient telephone service should be addressed to Congress. Pp.224-234.

UNITED STATES v. CARLTON
CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE NINTH CIRCUIT
No.92-1941. Argued February 28
As adopted in October 1986
column2: 26 U. S. C.  2057 granted an estate tax deduction for half the proceeds of ""any sale of employer securities by the executor of an estate"" to ""an employee stock ownership plan"" (ESOP). In December 1986
column3: respondent Carlton
column5: purchased shares in a corporation
column6: sold them to that company's ESOP at a loss
column7: and claimed a large  2057 deduction on his estate tax return. In December 1987
column10: the securities sold to an ESOP must have been ""directly owned"" by the decedent ""immediately before death."" Because the amendment applied retroactively
column11: as if it were incorporated in the original1986 provision
column12: the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) disallowed Carlton's  2057 deduction. The District Court entered summary judgment against him in his ensuing refund action
column13: rejecting his contention that the amendment's retroactive application to his transactions violated the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment. The Court of Appeals reversed
column14: holding that such application was rendered unduly harsh and oppressive
column16: by Carlton's lack of notice that  2057 would be retroactively amended and by his reasonable reliance to his detriment on pre amendment law.

column1: Held: The 1987 amendment's retroactive application to Carlton's 1986 transactions does not violate due process. Under the applicable standard
column2: a tax statute's retroactive application must be supported by a legitimate legislative purpose furthered by rational means. See
column3: e. g.
column4: Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation v. R. A. Gray & Co.
column7: Congress' purpose in enacting the 1987 amendment was neither illegitimate nor arbitrary. Section 2057 was originally intended to create an incentive for stockholders to sell their companies to their employees
column8: but the absence of a decedent-stock-ownership requirement resulted in the deduction's broad availability to virtually any estate
column9: at an estimated loss to the Government of up to $7 billion in anticipated revenues. Thus
column10: Congress undoubtedly intended the amendment to correct what it reasonably viewed as a mistake in the original provision. There is no plausible contention that it acted with an improper motive
column11: and its decision to prevent the unanticipated revenue loss by denying

column1: the deduction to those who made purely tax-motivated stock transfers was not unreasonable. Moreover
column2: the amendment's retroactive application is rationally related to its legitimate purpose
column3: since Congress acted promptly in proposing the amendment within a few months of  2057's original enactment and established a modest retroactivity period that extended only slightly longer than one year. The Court of Appeals' exclusive focus on the taxpayer's notice and reliance held  2057 to an unduly strict standard. Pp. 30-35.

CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE EIGHTH CIRCUIT
No. 92-1856. Argued February 23
An ordinance of petitioner City of Ladue bans all residential signs but those falling within 1 of 10 exemptions
column2: for the principal purpose of minimizing the visual clutter associated with such signs. Respondent Gilleo filed this action
column3: alleging that the ordinance violated her right to free speech by prohibiting her from displaying a sign stating
column5: from her home. The District Court found the ordinance unconstitutional
column6: and the Court of Appeals affirmed
column7: holding that the ordinance was a ""content based"" regulation
column8: and that Ladue's substantial interests in enacting it were not sufficiently compelling to support such a restriction.

column1: Held: The ordinance violates a Ladue resident's right to free speech.
(a) While signs pose distinctive problems and thus are subject to municipalities' police powers
column2: measures regulating them inevitably affect communication itself. Such a regulation may be challenged on the ground that it restricts too little speech because its exemptions discriminate on the basis of signs' messages
column3: or on the ground that it prohibits too much protected speech. For purposes of this case
column4: the validity of Ladue's submission that its ordinance's various exemptions are free of impermissible content or viewpoint discrimination is assumed. Pp.48-53.

column1: (b) Although Ladue has a concededly valid interest in minimizing visual clutter
column2: it has almost completely foreclosed an important and distinct medium of expression to political
column3: religious
column4: or personal messages. Prohibitions foreclosing entire media may be completely free of content or viewpoint discrimination
column5: but such measures can suppress too much speech by eliminating a common means of speaking. Pp. 54-55.

column1: (c) Ladue's attempt to justify the ordinance as a ""time
column3: or manner"" restriction fails because alternatives such as handbills and newspaper advertisements are inadequate substitutes for the important medium that Ladue has closed off. Displaying a sign from one's own residence carries a message quite distinct from placing the same sign someplace else
column4: or conveying the same text or picture by other means
column5: for it provides information about the speaker's identity
column6: an important component of many attempts to persuade. Residential signs are also

column1: Syllabus
an unusually cheap and convenient form of communication. Furthermore
column2: the audience intended to be reached by a residential sign-neighbors-could not be reached nearly as well by other means. Pp. 56-57.

column1: (d) A special respect for individual liberty in the home has long been part of this Nation's culture and law and has a special resonance when the government seeks to constrain a person's ability to speak there. The decision reached here does not leave Ladue powerless to address the ills that may be associated with residential signs. In addition
column2: residents' self-interest in maintaining their own property values and preventing ""visual clutter"" in their yards and neighborhoods diminishes the danger of an ""unlimited"" proliferation of signs. Pp. 58-59.

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK No. 93-377. Argued March 23
Enrolled tribal members purchasing cigarettes on Indian reservations are exempt from a New York cigarette tax
column2: but non-Indians making such purchases are not. Licensed agents pre collect the tax by purchasing stamps and affixing them to cigarette packs in ad vance of their first sale. Determining that a large volume of unstamped cigarettes was being purchased by non-Indians on reservations
column3: petitioner tax department enacted regulations imposing recordkeeping requirements and quantity limitations on cigarette wholesalers selling untaxed cigarettes to reservation Indians. As relevant here
column4: the regulations set quotas on the quantity of untaxed cigarettes that wholesalers may sell to tribes and tribal retailers
column5: and petitioner tax department must approve each such sale. Wholesalers must also ensure that a buyer holds a valid state tax exemption certificate
column6: and must keep records of their tax-exempt sales
column7: make monthly reports to petitioners
column10: precollect taxes on nonexempt sales. Respondent wholesalers are licensed by the Bureau of Indian Affairs to sell cigarettes to reservation Indians. They filed separate suits in state court alleging that the regulations were pre-empted by the federal Indian Trader Statutes. The trial court issued an injunction. Ultimately
column11: the Appellate Division upheld the regulations
column12: but the Court of Appeals reversed
column13: distinguishing this Court's decisions upholding taxes imposed on non-Indian purchasers of cigarettes
column14: see Moe v. Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes of Flathead Reservation
column15: 425 U. S. 463; Washington v. Confederated Tribes of Colville Reservation
column17: on the ground that they involved regulating sales to non-Indian consumers whereas New York's regulations applied to sales by non-Indian wholesalers to reservation Indians. The court concluded that the Indian Trader Statutes
column18: as construed in Warren Trading Post Co. v. Arizona Tax Comm'n
column20: deprived the States of all power to impose regulatory burdens on licensed Indian traders
column23: that if States could impose minimal burdens on the traders
column24: New York's regulations were invalid because the burdens were significant.

column1: Held: New York's regulations do not
column3: violate the Indian Trader Statutes. pp. 69-78.

Syllabus
(a) Because respondents have made essentially a facial challenge
column2: this case is confined to those alleged defects that inhere in the regulations as written
column3: and the Court need not assess for all purposes each feature of the tax scheme that might affect tribal self-government or federal authority over Indian affairs. Pp. 69-70.

column1: (b) Indian traders are not wholly immune from state regulation that is reasonably necessary to the assessment or collection of lawful state taxes. Although broad language in Warren Trading Post suggests such immunity
column2: that proposition has been undermined by subsequent decisions in M oe (upholding a state law requiring Indian retailers on tribal land to collect a state cigarette tax imposed on sales to non-Indians)
column3: Colville (upholding in relevant part a state law requiring tribal retailers on reservations to collect cigarette taxes on sales to nonmembers and to keep extensive records)
column4: and Oklahoma Tax Comm'n v. Citizen Band of Potawatomi Tribe of Okla.
column5: 498 U. S. 505. These cases have made clear that the States have a valid interest in ensuring compliance with lawful taxes that might easily be evaded through purchases of taxexempt cigarettes on reservations; that interest outweighs tribes' modest interest in offering a tax exemption to customers who would ordinarily shop elsewhere. Thus
column6: there is more room for state regulation in this area. In particular
column7: these cases have decided that States may impose on reservation retailers minimal burdens reasonably tailored to the collection of valid taxes from non-Indians. It would be anomalous to hold that a State could impose tax collection and bookkeeping burdens on reservation retailers who are enrolled tribal members but not on wholesalers

column1: (c) New York's scheme does not impose excessive burdens on Indian traders. Respondents' objections to the regulations setting quotas and requiring that petitioners pre approve deliveries provide no basis for a facial challenge
column2: although the possibility of inadequate quotas may provide a basis for a future challenge to the regulations' application. The requirements that wholesalers sell untaxed cigarettes only to persons with valid exemption certificates and keep detailed records are no more demanding than comparable measures approved in Colville. Moreover
column3: the precollection obligation placed on wholesalers is the same as the obligation that
column5: may be imposed on reservation retailers. The United States' arguments supporting its position that the scheme improperly burdens Indian trading are also rejected. pp.75-78.

column3: reversed.

column2: receiver for an insolvent California savings and loan (S&L)
column3: caused the S&L to make refunds to investors in certain fraudulent real estate syndications in which the S&L had been represented by petitioner law firm. The FDIC filed suit against petitioner in the Federal District Court and alleged state causes of action for professional negligence and breach of fiduciary duty. Petitioner moved for summary judgment
column5: inter alia
column6: that knowledge of the fraudulent conduct of the S&Us officers must be imputed to the S&L
column7: and hence to the FDIC
column10: stood in the S&Us shoes; and thus the FDIC was estopped from pursuing its tort claims. The court granted the motion
column11: but the Court of Appeals reversed
column12: indicating that a federal common-law rule of decision controlled.

column1: Held: The California rule of decision
column3: governs petitioner's tort liability. Pp. 83-89.

column1: (a) State law governs the imputation of corporate officers' knowledge to a corporation that is asserting causes of action created by state law. There is no federal general common law
column5: and the remote possibility that corporations may go into federal receivership is no conceivable basis for adopting a special federal common-law rule divesting States of authority over the entire law of imputation. Pp. 83-85.

column1: (b) California law also governs the narrower question whether corporate officers' knowledge can be imputed to the FDIC suing as receiver. This Court will not adopt a judge-made federal rule to supplement comprehensive and detailed federal statutory regulation; matters left unaddressed in such a scheme are presumably left to state law. Title 12 U. S. C.  1821(d)(2)(A)(i)-which states that ""the [FDIC] shall
column3: succeed to-all rights
column5: powers
column6: and privileges of the insured depository institution""-places the FDIC in the insolvent S&L's shoes to pursue its claims under state law
column7: except where some provision in the extensive framework of the Financial Institutions Re-

column1: form
column3: and Enforcement Act of 1989 (FIRREA) specifically creates a special federal rule of decision. Pp. 85-87.

column1: (c) Judicial creation of a special federal rule would not be justified even if FIR REA is inapplicable to the instant receivership
column2: which began in 1986. Instances where a special federal rule is warranted are few and restricted
column3: limited to situations where there is a significant conflict between some federal policy or interest and the use of state law. The FDIC has identified no significant conflict here
column4: not even one implicating the most lightly invoked federal interest: uniformity. Pp. 87-89.

CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE SIXTH CIRCUIT
No. 92-8556. Argued January 10
Mter petitioner Nichols pleaded guilty to federal felony drug charges
column2: he was assessed criminal history points under the United States Sentencing Guidelines
column3: including one point for a state misdemeanor conviction for driving while under the influence (DUI)
column4: for which he was fined but not incarcerated. That point increased the maximum sentence of imprisonment from 210 to 235 months. Petitioner objected to the inclusion of his DUI conviction
column5: arguing that because he had not been represented by counsel in that proceeding
column6: considering it in establishing his sentence would violate the Sixth Amendment as construed in Baldasar v. Illinois
column7: 446 U. S. 222. However
column8: the District Court reasoned that Baldasar lacked a majority opinion and thus stood only for the proposition that a prior uncounseled misdemeanor conviction may not be used to create a felony with a prison term. Since petitioner's offense was already defined as a felony
column9: the court ruled that Baldasar was inapplicable and sentenced petitioner to a term of imprisonment 25 months longer than it could have been had the DUI conviction not been considered. The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held: Consistent with the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments
column2: a sentencing court may consider a defendant's previous uncounseled misdemeanor conviction in sentencing him for a subsequent offense so long as the previous uncounseled misdemeanor conviction did not result in a sentence of imprisonment. Pp. 743-749.

column1: (a) A year after this Court decided that a defendant charged with a misdemeanor has no constitutional right to counsel where no sentence of imprisonment is imposed
column4: a majority of the Court held in Baldasar that a prior uncounseled misdemeanor conviction
column5: constitutional under Scott
column6: could not be collaterally used to convert a second misdemeanor conviction into a felony under the applicable Illinois sentencing enhancement statute. However
column7: that per curiam opinion provided no rationale for its result

Montana law enforcement officers raided the farm of respondents-members of the extended Kurth family-arrested them
column2: and confiscated and later destroyed their marijuana plants. Mter the Kurths pleaded guilty to drug charges
column3: petitioner revenue department attempted
column5: to collect a state tax imposed on the possession and storage of dangerous drugs. That tax is collected only after any state or federal fines or forfeitures have been satisfied
column6: and taxpayers must file a return after they are arrested. In bankruptcy proceedings filed by the Kurths
column7: they objected to petitioner's proof of claim for the tax and challenged the tax's constitutionality. The Bankruptcy Court held
column9: that the assessment on harvested marijuana

column11: was a form of double jeopardy invalid under the Federal Constitution
column12: and the District Court affirmed. In affirming
column13: the Court of Appeals determined that the central inquiry under United States v. Halper
column15: is whether the sanction imposed is rationally related to the damages the government suffered
