column17: and that the tax was unconstitutional as applied to them because the State refused to offer any such evidence.

column1: Held: The tax violates the constitutional prohibition against successive punishments for the same offense. Pp.776-784.
(a) Although deciding in Halper that a legislature's description of a statute as civil does not foreclose the possibility that it has a punitive character
column2: and that a defendant convicted and punished for an offense may not have a nonremedial civil penalty imposed against him for the same offense in a separate proceeding
column3: the Court did not consider whether a tax may similarly be characterized as punitive. However
column4: the Court's recognition that the extension of a so-called tax's penalizing feature can cause it to lose its character as such and become a mere penalty
column5: A. Magnano Co. v. Hamilton
column8: together with Halper's unequivocal statement that labels do not control in a double jeopardy inquiry
column9: indicates that a tax is not immune from double jeopardy scrutiny simply because it is a tax. Pp.776-780.

column1: Syllabus
(b) While taxes are usually motivated by revenue-raising rather than punitive purposes
column2: Montana's tax departs far from normal revenue laws. Its high rate and deterrent purpose
column3: in and of themselves
column4: do not necessarily render it punitive
column5: but other unusual features set it apart from most taxes. That it is conditioned on the commission of a crime is significant of penal and prohibitory intent rather than the gathering of revenue. It is also exacted only after the taxpayer has been arrested for the precise conduct that gives rise to the tax obligation in the first place. Since the taxed activity is completely forbidden
column6: the legitimate revenue-raising purpose that might support the tax could be equally well served by increasing the fine imposed upon conviction. In addition
column7: it purports to be a property tax
column8: yet it is levied on goods-here
column9: the destroyed marijuana plants-that the taxpayer neither owns nor possesses. Pp. 780-783.

column1: (c) Since tax statutes serve a purpose quite different from civil penalties
column2: it is inappropriate to subject Montana's tax to Halper's test for a civil penalty: whether the penalty is imposed as a remedy for actual costs to the State that are attributable to the defendant's conduct. Moreover
column3: Montana has not claimed that its assessments can be justified on such grounds
column4: and the same formula would have been used to compute the assessment regardless of the State's damages or whether it suffered any damages. Montana's tax is not the kind of remedial sanction that may follow the first punishment of a criminal offense. It is a second punishment that must be imposed during the first prosecution or not at all. P. 784.

(a) Prison officials have a duty under the Eighth Amendment to provide humane conditions of confinement. They must ensure that inmates receive adequate food
column3: shelter
column5: and must protect prisoners from violence at the hands of other prisoners. However

column3: it is the equivalent of acting recklessly. However
column4: this does not establish the level of culpability deliberate indifference entails
column5: for the term recklessness is not self-defining
column6: and can take subjective or objective forms. Pp.835-837.

column1: (c) Subjective recklessness
column2: as used in the criminal law
column3: is the appropriate test for ""deliberate indifference."" Permitting a finding of recklessness only when a person has disregarded a risk of harm of which he was aware is a familiar and workable standard that is consistent with the Cruel and Unusual Punishments Clause as interpreted in this Court's cases. The Eighth Amendment outlaws cruel and unusual ""punishments
column5: and the failure to alleviate a significant risk that an official should have perceived but did not

column7: cannot be condemned as the infliction of punishment under the Court's cases. column5: and a factfinder may conclude that the official knew of a substantial risk from the very fact that it was obvious. Nor may an official escape liability by showing that he knew of the risk but did not think that the complainant was especially likely to be assaulted by the prisoner who committed the act. It does not matter whether the risk came from a particular source or whether a prisoner faced the risk for reasons personal to him or because all prisoners in his situation faced the risk. Employees are considered ""supervisors
column2: and thus are not covered under the National Labor Relations Act
column5: requiring the use of independent judgment

column10: monitor and evaluate the work of nurses' aides

column3: 688. Since patient care is a nursing home's business
column4: it follows that attending to the needs of patients

column9: interpreting the phrase ""in the interest of an employer."" Pp. 576-580.

column1: (b) The Board's nonstatutory arguments supporting its interpretation are unpersuasive. The Act must be enforced according to its
own terms
column2: not by creating legal categories inconsistent with its meaning. Nor can the tension between the Act's exclusion of supervisory and managerial employees and its inclusion of professionals be resolved by distorting the statutory language in the manner proposed by the Board. In addition
column3: an isolated statement in the legislative history of the 1974 amendments to the Act-expressing apparent approval of the application of the Board's then-current supervisory test to nurses-does not represent an authoritative interpretation of the phrase ""in the interest of the employer"" enacted by Congress in 1947. STAPLES v. UNITED STATES
CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE TENTH CIRCUIT
No.92-1441. Argued November 30
The National Firearms Act criminalizes possession of an unregistered ""firearm
column3: including a ""machinegun
column5: which is defined as a weapon that automatically fires more than one shot with a single pull of the trigger
column6: 5845(b). Petitioner Staples was charged with possessing an unregistered machine gun in violation of  5861(d) after officers searching his home seized a semiautomatic riflei. e.
column7: a weapon that normally fires only one shot with each trigger pullthat had apparently been modified for fully automatic fire. At trial
column8: Staples testified that the rifle had never fired automatically while he possessed it and that he had been ignorant of any automatic firing capability. He was convicted after the District Court rejected his proposed jury instruction under which
column10: the Government would have been required to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that Staples knew that the gun would fire fully automatically. The Court of Appeals affirmed
column11: concluding that the Government need not prove a defendant's knowledge of a weapon's physical properties to obtain a conviction under  5861(d).

column1: Held: To obtain a  5861(d) conviction
column2: the Government should have been required to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that Staples knew that his rifle had the characteristics that brought it within the statutory definition of a machinegun. Pp. 604-619.

column1: (a) The common-law rule requiring mens rea as an element of a crime informs interpretation of  5861(d) in this case. Because some indication of congressional intent
column3: is required to dispense with mens rea
column4: 5861(d)'s silence on the element of knowledge required for a conviction does not suggest that Congress intended to dispense with a conventional mens rea requirement
column5: which would require that the defendant know the facts making his conduct illegal. Pp. 604-606.

column1: (b) The Court rejects the Government's argument that the Act fits within the Court's line of precedent concerning ""public welfare"" or ""regulatory"" offenses and thus that the presumption favoring mens rea does not apply in this case. In cases concerning public welfare offenses
column2: the Court has inferred from silence a congressional intent to dispense with conventional mens rea requirements in statutes that regulate potentially harmful or injurious items. In such cases
column3: the Court has reasoned

column1: that as long as a defendant knows that he is dealing with a dangerous device of a character that places him in responsible relation to a public danger
column2: he should be alerted to the probability of strict regulation
column3: and is placed on notice that he must determine at his peril whether his conduct comes within the statute's inhibition. See
column5: United States v. Balint
column6: 258 U. S. 250; United States v. Freed
column7: 401 U. S. 601. Guns
column9: do not fall within the category of dangerous devices as it has been developed in public welfare offense cases. In contrast to the selling of dangerous drugs at issue in Balint or the possession of hand grenades considered in Freed
column10: private ownership of guns in this country has enjoyed a long tradition of being entirely lawful conduct. Thus
column11: the destructive potential of guns in general cannot be said to put gun owners sufficiently on notice of the likelihood of regulation to justify interpreting  5861 (d) as dispensing with proof of knowledge of the characteristics that make a weapon a ""firearm"" under the statute. The Government's interpretation potentially would impose criminal sanctions on a class of persons whose mental state-ignorance of the characteristics of weapons in their possession-makes their actions entirely innocent. Had Congress intended to make outlaws of such citizens
column12: it would have spoken more clearly to that effect. Pp. 606-616.

column1: (c) The potentially harsh penalty attached to violation of  5861 (d)up to 10 years' imprisonment-confirms the foregoing reading of the Act. Where
column3: dispensing with mens rea would require the defendant to have knowledge only of traditionally lawful conduct
column4: a severe penalty is a further factor tending to suggest that Congress did not intend to eliminate a mens rea requirement. Pp. 616-619.

column1: (d) The holding here is a narrow one that depends on a commonsense evaluation of the nature of the particular device Congress has subjected to regulation
column2: the expectations that individuals may legitimately have in dealing with that device
column3: and the penalty attached to a violation. It does not set forth comprehensive criteria for distinguishing between crimes that require a mental element and crimes that do not. Pp. 619-620.

column3: ET AL.

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE SUPREME COURT OF MISSOURI No. 93-397. Argued March 28
Missouri's uniform
column2: statewide ""additional use tax"" on goods purchased outside the State and stored
column3: used
column4: or consumed within the State is purportedly designed to ""compensate"" for the taxes imposed by local jurisdictions within the State on in-state sales of goods. Local sales tax rates
column5: however
column6: vary widely
column7: and in many jurisdictions the use tax exceeds the sales tax. Petitioners-a trade association representing businesses that must collect the additional use tax and a manufacturer that pays it-brought this action in state court
column8: contending that the tax scheme impermissibly discriminates against interstate commerce in violation of the Commerce Clause. The State Circuit Court granted respondents summary judgment. In affirming
column9: the Supreme Court of Missouri reasoned that
column10: because the tax was designed to even exactions on intrastate and interstate trade
column11: the tax scheme should be analyzed under the ""compensatory tax"" doctrine. The court concluded that
column12: given the high average rate of local jurisdictions' sales taxes
column13: the overall effect of the use tax scheme across the State was to place a lighter aggregate tax burden on interstate commerce than on intrastate commerce
column14: even though in some localities the use tax might exceed the sales tax. The court determined that
column16: there was no discrimination against interstate commerce on a statewide basis and held that the use tax scheme did not violate the Commerce Clause.

column1: Held: Missouri's use tax scheme impermissibly discriminates against interstate commerce in those localities where the use tax exceeds the sales tax. Pp. 646-657.

(a) Although the compensatory tax doctrine saves from constitutional infirmity a facially discriminatory tax that imposes on interstate commerce the equivalent of an ""identifiable and substantially similar tax on intrastate commerce
column3: Inc. v. Department of Environmental Quality of Ore.
column5: at 103
column6: Missouri's use tax scheme runs afoul of the basic requirement that
column7: for a tax system to be ""compensatory
column8: the burdens imposed on interstate and intrastate commerce must be equal
column13: 584-587. Whether the use tax is equal to (or lower than) the local sales tax is a matter of fortuity in Missouri

column1: in which the Missouri purchaser happens to reside. In jurisdictions where the use tax exceeds the sales tax
column2: the discrepancy imposes a discriminatory burden on interstate commerce. The State Supreme Court's statewide averaging approach is contrary to this Court's decisions
column3: which have
column5: implicitly rejected any theory that would require aggregating the burdens on commerce across an entire State to determine the constitutionality of an exaction imposed on interstate trade by a particular political subdivision. See Fort Gratiot Sanitary Landfill
column6: Inc. v. Michigan Dept. of Natural Resources
column8: 363. General American Tank Car Corp. v. Day
column11: distinguished. Requiring equal treatment of intrastate and interstate commerce not only across the State as a whole
column12: but also within each political subdivision of the State
column13: does not effectively eliminate the State's ability to delegate taxing authority to local jurisdictions. It merely prohibits the State from granting its subdivisions a power to discriminate that the State lacked in the first instance. Pp. 646-654.

column1: (b) The Court rejects petitioners' contention that the use tax should be struck down in its entirety. Petitioners argue that the tax should be treated as facially invalid in every jurisdiction because there is no countervailing statewide sales tax and no legislation ensuring that local sales taxes will always equal or exceed the use tax. But it is the actual discrimination that results from the Missouri tax system in some localities
column2: not the potential for discrimination in every locality
column3: that transgresses constitutional commands. See
column5: Gregg Dyeing Co. v. Query

column1: (c) The effect that any pre deprivation procedures provided under state law for contesting the use tax might have on the appropriate remedy in this case
column2: as well as determination of the methods best adapted to implementing a remedy here
column3: are matters best left for consideration on remand. Pp. 656-657.

column4: by preventing everyone except the favored local operator from performing the initial processing step. P. 389.

column4: 624. Although the ordinance erects no barrier to the import or export of any

column2: and while he was still in the custody of those officers
column3: respondent confessed to United States Secret Service agents that he knew that Federal Reserve Notes the local officers had discovered while searching his home were counterfeit. column5: inter alia
column6: respondent's argument that the delay between his arrest on state charges and his presentment on the federal charge rendered the confession inadmissible under 18 U. S. C.  3501(c)

column8: shall not be inadmissible solely because of delay in bringing such person before [a judicial officer] empowered to commit persons charged with offenses against the laws of the United States"" if the confession was made voluntarily and ""within six hours"" following the arrest or other detention. column11: 3501(c) permits suppression in cases where a confession is made outside the subsection's 6-hour post-arrest safe harbor period. column1: Held: Section 3501(c) does not apply to statements made by a person who is being held solely on state charges. Pp. 355-360.
(a) The subsection's text clearly indicates that its terms were never triggered in this case. Respondent errs in suggesting that
column2: because the statute refers to a person in the custody of ""any"" law enforcement officer or agency
column3: the 6-hour time period begins to run whenever a person is arrested by local
column5: or federal officers. The subsection can apply only when there is some ""delay"" in presenting a person to a federal judicial officer. Because the term delay presumes an obligation to act
column6: there can be no ""delay"" in bringing a person before a federal judicial officer until there is some obligation to do so in the first place. Such a

column1: duty does not arise until the person is arrested or detained for a federal crime. Although a person arrested on a federal charge by any officerlocal
column3: or federal-is under ""arrest or other detention"" for the purposes of  3501(c) and its safe harbor period
column4: one arrested on state charges is not. This is true even if the arresting officers believe or have cause to believe that federal law also has been violated
column5: because such a belief does not alter the underlying basis for the arrest and subsequent custody. Pp. 355-358.

Section 3501(c)'s terms thus did not come into play until he was arrested on a federal charge-after he made the statement. column3: because in this case there was no such collusive arrangement

Mter a bench trial in petitioner Landgraf's suit under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (Title VII)
column2: the District Court found that she had been sexually harassed by a co-worker at respondent USI Film Products
column3: but that the harassment was not so severe as to justify her decision to resign her position. Because the court found that her employment was not terminated in violation of Title VII
column4: she was not entitled to equitable relief

column6: the court dismissed her complaint. While her appeal was pending
column7: the Civil Rights Act of 1991 (1991 Act or Act) became law
column8: 102 of which includes provisions that create a right to recover compensatory and punitive damages for intentional discrimination violative of Title VII (hereinafter  102(a))
column9: and authorize any party to demand a jury trial if such damages are claimed (hereinafter  102(c)). In affirming
column10: the Court of Appeals rejected Landgraf's argument that her case should be remanded for a jury trial on damages pursuant to  102.

column1: Held: Section 102 does not apply to a Title VII case that was pending on appeal when the 1991 Act was enacted. Pp. 250-286.
(a) Since the President vetoed a 1990 version of the Act on the ground
column3: of perceived unfairness in the bill's elaborate retroactivity provision
column4: it is likely that the omission of comparable language in the 1991 Act was not congressional oversight or unawareness
column5: but was a compromise that made the Act possible. That omission is not dispositive here because it does not establish precisely where the compromise was struck. For example
column6: a decision to reach only cases still pending
column7: and not those already finally decided
column8: might explain Congress' failure to provide in the 1991 Act
column9: as it had in the 1990 bill
column10: that certain sections would apply to proceedings pending on specified preenactment dates. Pp. 250-257.

column1: (b) The text of the 1991 Act does not evince any clear expression of congressional intent as to whether  102 applies to cases arising before the Act's passage. The provisions on which Landgraf relies for such an expression- 402(a)
column3: ""[e]xcept as otherwise specifically provided
column4: this Act and the amendments made by this Act shall take effect upon enactment
column5: and  402(b) and 109(c)
column6: which provide for prospective application in limited contexts-cannot bear the heavy

column1: weight she would place upon them by negative inference: Her statutory argument would require the Court to assume that Congress chose a surprisingly indirect route to convey an important and easily expressed message. Moreover
column2: the relevant legislative history reveals little to suggest that Members of Congress believed that an agreement had been tacitly reached on the controversial retroactivity issue or that Congress understood or intended the interplay of the foregoing sections to have the decisive effect Landgraf assigns them. Instead
column3: the history conveys the impression that legislators agreed to disagree about whether and to what extent the Act would apply to pre enactment conduct. pp. 257-263.

column1: (c) In order to resolve the question left open by the 1991 Act
column2: this Court must focus on the apparent tension between two seemingly contradictory canons for interpreting statutes that do not specify their temporal reach: the rule that a court must apply the law in effect at the time it renders its decision
column3: see Bradley v. School Bd. of Richmond
column6: and the axiom that statutory retroactivity is not favored
column7: see Bowen v. Georgetown Univ. Hospital

column1: (d) The presumption against statutory retroactivity is founded upon elementary considerations of fairness dictating that individuals should have an opportunity to know what the law is and to conform their conduct accordingly. It is deeply rooted in this Court's jurisprudence and finds expression in several constitutional provisions
column3: in the criminal context
column4: the Ex Post Facto Clause. In the civil context
column5: prospectivity remains the appropriate default rule unless Congress has made clear its intent to disrupt settled expectations. Pp. 265-273.

CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE EIGHTH CIRCUIT
No. 92-1546. Argued December 6
As a result of Sally Ordway Irvine's 1979 disclaimer of five-sixteenths of her interest in the corpus of a recently terminated trust that had been created by her grandfather in 1917
column2: each of her five children received one-sixteenth of her share of the distributed trust principal. Her disclaimer was effective under Minnesota law even though she had learned of her contingent interest in the trust at least as early as 1931 when she became 21
column3: but the Internal Revenue Service determined that the disclaimer brought about a gratuitous transfer that was subject to federal gift tax under Internal Revenue Code  2501(a)(1) and 2511(a). Mrs. Irvine died after she paid the tax and accrued interest
column5: representing her estate
column6: filed this refund action. Arguing that the transaction was not excepted from gift tax under Treasury Regulation 25.2511-1(c)(2) (Regulation)
column7: the Government relied on Jewett v. Commissioner
column9: in which this Court construed the 1958 version of the Regulation to provide that the disclaimer of a remainder interest in a trust effects a taxable gift to the beneficiary of the disclaimer unless the disclaimant acts within a reasonable time after learning of the transfer that created the interest being disclaimed. Respondents attempted to distinguish Jewett as having dealt with a trust established in 1939
column10: after the creation of the gift tax by the Revenue Act of 1932 (Act). The District Court ruled for respondents on cross-motions for summary judgment. The Court of Appeals affirmed
column11: holding that the Regulation's express terms rendered it inapplicable to the trust in question; that state law therefore governed
column12: and the federal gift tax did not apply because Mrs. Irvine's disclaimer was indisputably valid under state law; and that taxation of the transfer effected by the disclaimer would violate the Act's prohibition of retroactive gift taxation.

column1: Held: The disclaimer of a remainder interest in a trust is subject to federal gift taxation when the creation of the interest (but not the disclaimer) occurred before enactment of the gift tax. Pp.232-242.
(a) Although the Internal Revenue Code's gift tax provisions embrace all gratuitous transfers of property having significant value
column2: the Regulation affords an exception by providing that a disclaimer of property

column1: transferred from a decedent's estate does not result in a gift if it is unequivocal and effective under local law
column2: and made ""within a reasonable time after knowledge of the existence of the transfer."" The Jewett Court held that ""the transfer"" in the 1958 version of the Regulation refers to the creation of the interest being disclaimed
column3: with the ""reasonable time"" therefore beginning to run upon knowledge of the creation of the trust. Pp. 232-234.

column1: (b) If the Regulation applies to Mrs. Irvine's disclaimer
column2: her act resulted in taxable gifts. The knowledge and capacity to act
column3: which are presupposed by the requirement that a tax-free disclaimer be made within a reasonable time of the disclaimant's knowledge of the transfer of the interest to her
column4: were present in this instance at least as early as Mrs. Irvine's 21st birthday in 1931. Although there is no bright-line rule for timeliness in the absence of a statute or regulation providing one
column5: Mrs. Irvine's delay for at least 47 years in making her disclaimer could not possibly be thought reasonable. Pp. 234-236.

column1: (c) Respondents' arguments that the Regulation is inapposite by its own terms to the facts of this case need not be resolved here
column2: for the result of the Regulation's inapplicability would not be
column3: as respondents claim
column4: a freedom from gift taxation on a theory of borrowed state law. State property transfer rules do not translate into federal taxation rules because the principles underlying the two look to different objects. In order to defeat the claims of a disclaimant's creditors in the disclaimed property
column5: the state rules apply the legal fiction that an effective disclaimer of a testamentary gift cancels the transfer to the disclaimant ab initio and substitutes a single transfer from the original donor to the disclaimant's beneficiary. In contrast
column6: Congress enacted the gift tax as a supplement to the federal estate tax and a means of curbing estate tax avoidance. Since the reasons for defeating a disclaimant's creditors would furnish no reasons for defeating the gift tax
column7: the Court in Jewett
column10: was undoubtedly correct to hold that Congress had not meant to incorporate state-law fictions as touchstones of taxability when it enacted the Act. Absent such a legal fiction
column11: the federal gift tax is not struck blind by a disclaimer. Pp. 236-240.

column1: (d) Taxation of the transfer following Mrs. Irvine's disclaimer would not violate  501(b) of the Act
column2: which provided that it would ""not apply to a transfer made on or before the date of the enactment of this Act [June 6
column3: 1932]."" Section 501 merely prohibited application of the gift tax statute to transfers antedating the enactment of the Act; it did not prohibit taxation where
column5: interests created before the Act were transferred after enactment. Pp.240-241.

column3: supported by history

Respondents were members of a class whose money damages claims were settled in a suit filed against petitioner title insurance companies. The class was certified under Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 23(b)(1)(A) and (b)(2)
column2: which do not permit class members to opt out of a class. When respondent Brown subsequently filed the present action on behalf of Arizona and Wisconsin title insurance consumers
column3: the District Court granted petitioners summary judgment on the ground that respondents were bound by the earlier judgment. The Ninth Circuit reversed
column4: holding that it would violate due process to accord res judicata effect to a judgment involving money damages claims where a plaintiff to the previous suit had not been afforded a right to opt out.

column1: Held: Because deciding this case would require the Court to resolve a constitutional question that may be entirely hypothetical
column2: the writ is dismissed as improvidently granted. The Court would not have to reach the question whether absent class members have a constitutional right to opt out of actions involving money damages if it turned out that classes in such actions can be certified only under Rule 23(b)(3)
column3: which permits opt out. However
column4: the determination that respondents' class fit within Rules 23(b)(1)(A) and (b)(2) is conclusive upon these parties
column5: and the alternative of using the Federal Rules instead of the Constitution as a means of imposing an opt-out requirement on this settlement is no longer available. Further
column6: it is not clear that our resolution of the constitutional question will make any difference even to these litigants.

column3: the District Court denied his motion for attorney's fees pursuant to 17 U. S. C.  505
column4: which provides in relevant part that in such an action ""the court may ... award a reasonable attorney's fee to the prevailing party as part of the costs."" The Court of Appeals affirmed

column1: Held: Prevailing plaintiffs and prevailing defendants must be treated alike under  505; attorney's fees are to be awarded to prevailing parties only as a matter of the court's discretion. Pp. 522-535.

(a) Fantasy's arguments in favor of a dual standard are rejected. Section 505's language gives no hint that successful plaintiffs are to be treated differently than successful defendants. Nor does this Court's decision in Christiansburg Garment Co. v. EEOC
column3: which construed virtually identical language from Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964
column4: support different treatment. The normal indication that fee-shifting statutes with similar language should be interpreted alike is overborne by factors relied upon in Christiansburg and the Civil Rights Act which are noticeably absent in the context of the Copyright Act. The legislative history of  505 provides no support for different treatment. In addition
column5: the two Acts' goals and objectives are not completely similar. The Civil Rights Act provides incentives for the bringing of meritorious lawsuits by impecunious ""private attorney general"" plaintiffs who can ill afford to litigate their claims against defendants with more resources. However
column6: the Copyright Act's primary objective is to encourage the production of original literary
column7: artistic
column8: and musical expression for the public good; and plaintiffs
column10: can run the gamut from corporate behemoths to starving artists. Fantasy's argument that the dual approach to  505 best serves the Copyright Act's policy of encouraging litigation of meritorious infringement claims expresses a one-sided view of the Copyright Act's purposes. Because copyright law ultimately serves the purpose of enriching the general

column1: Syllabus
public through access to creative works
column2: it is peculiarly important that the law's boundaries be demarcated as clearly as possible. Thus
column3: a defendant seeking to advance meritorious copyright defenses should be encouraged to litigate them to the same extent that plaintiffs are encouraged to litigate meritorious infringement claims. Fantasy also errs in urging that the legislative history supports the dual standard based on the principle of ratification. Neither the two studies submitted to Congress while it considered revisions to the Act
column4: nor the cases referred to in those studies
column5: support the view that there was a settled construction in favor of the dual standard under the virtually identical provision in the 1909 Copyright Act. Pp. 522-533.

column1: (b) Also rejected is Fogerty's argument that  505 enacted the ""British Rule
column2: which allows for automatic recovery of attorney's fees by prevailing plaintiffs and defendants
column3: absent exceptional circumstances. The word ""may"" in  505 clearly connotes discretion in awarding such fees

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE ET AL. v. FEDERAL LABOR RELATIONS AUTHORITY ET AL.
CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE FIFTH CIRCUIT
No. 92-1223. Argued November 8

Two local unions filed unfair labor practice charges with respondent Federal Labor Relations Authority after petitioner federal agencies refused to provide them with the home addresses of agency employees in the bargaining units represented by the unions. The Authority concluded that the Federal Service Labor-Management Relations Statute (Labor Statute) required the agencies to divulge the addresses and rejected petitioners' argument that such disclosure was prohibited by the Privacy Act of 1974. The Court of Appeals granted enforcement of the Authority's disclosure orders. It agreed that the Privacy Act did not bar disclosure because disclosure would be required under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). In determining that FOIA Exemption 6which exempts from disclosure personnel files ""the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy""did not apply

column1: 2. RICO does not require proof that either the racketeering enterprise or the predicate acts of racketeering in  1962(c) were motivated by an economic purpose. Nowhere in either  1962(c) or in  1961's

column2: 1962(c)'s language also includes enterprises whose activities ""affect"" such commerce. Webster's Third New International Dictionary defines ""affect"" as ""to have a detrimental influence on""; and an enterprise surely can have such an influence on commerce without having its own profit-seeking motives. column5: an ""enterprise"" is an entity acquired through illegal activity or the money generated from illegal activity: the victim of the activity. By contrast
column6: the ""enterprise"" in subsection (c) connotes generally the vehicle through which the unlawful pattern of racketeering activity is committed. Since it is not being acquired
column7: it need not have a property interest that can be acquired nor an economic motive for engaging in illegal activity; it need only be an association in fact that engages in a pattern of racketeering activity. column3: ET AL. v. SCHEIDLER ET AL.

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE SEVENTH CIRCUIT
No. 92-780. Argued December 8
In this action
column3: among other things
column5: a coalition of antiabortion groups called the Pro-Life Action Network (PLAN) and others
column6: were members of a nationwide conspiracy to shut down abortion clinics through a pattern of racketeering activity-including extortion under the Hobbs Act-in violation of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) chapter of the Organized Crime Control Act of 1970
column7: 18 U. S. C.  1961-1968. They claimed that respondents conspired to use threatened or actual force
column9: or fear to induce clinic employees
column11: and patients to give up their jobs
column13: and their right to obtain clinic services; that the conspiracy injured the clinics' business and property interests; and that PLAN is a racketeering enterprise. The District Court dismissed the case pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6). It found that the clinics failed to state a claim under  1962(c)-which makes it unlawful ""for any person employed by or associated with any enterprise engaged in
column14: or the activities of which affect
column16: to conduct or participate ... in the conduct of such enterprise's affairs through a pattern of racketeering activity or collection of unlawful debt"" -because they did not allege a profit-generating purpose in the activity or enterprise. It also dismissed their conspiracy claim under  1962(d) on the ground that the  1962(c) and other RICO claims they made could not stand. The Court of Appeals affirmed
column17: agreeing that there is an economic motive requirement implicit in  1962(c)'s enterprise element.

column1: Held:
1. The clinics have standing to bring their claim. Since their complaint was dismissed at the pleading stage
column2: the complaint must be sustained if relief could be granted under any set offacts that could be proved consistent with the allegations. Hishon v. King & Spalding
column4: 73. Nothing more than the complaint's extortion and injury allegations are needed to confer standing at this stage. Pp. 255-256.

column1: 2. RICO does not require proof that either the racketeering enterprise or the predicate acts of racketeering in  1962(c) were motivated by an economic purpose. Nowhere in either  1962(c) or in  1961's
Syllabus

definitions of ""enterprise"" and ""pattern of racketeering activity"" is there any indication that such a motive is required. While arguably an enterprise engaged in interstate or foreign commerce would have a profitseeking motive
column2: 1962(c)'s language also includes enterprises whose activities ""affect"" such commerce. Webster's Third New International Dictionary defines ""affect"" as ""to have a detrimental influence on""; and an enterprise surely can have such an influence on commerce without having its own profit-seeking motives. The use of the term ""enterprise"" in subsections (a) and (b)
column3: where it is arguably more tied in with economic motivation
column4: also does not lead to the inference of an economic motive requirement in subsection (c). In subsections (a) and (b)
column5: an ""enterprise"" is an entity acquired through illegal activity or the money generated from illegal activity: the victim of the activity. By contrast
column6: the ""enterprise"" in subsection (c) connotes generally the vehicle through which the unlawful pattern of racketeering activity is committed. Since it is not being acquired
column7: it need not have a property interest that can be acquired nor an economic motive for engaging in illegal activity; it need only be an association in fact that engages in a pattern of racketeering activity. Nor is an economic motive requirement supported by the congressional statement of findings that prefaces RICO and refers to activities that drain billions of dollars from America's economy. Predicate acts
column8: such as the alleged extortion here
column9: may not benefit the protesters financially
column10: but they still may drain money from the economy by harming businesses such as the clinics. Moreover
column11: a statement of congressional findings is a rather thin reed upon which to base a requirement neither expressed nor fairly implied from the Act's operative sections. Cf. United States v. Turkette
column12: 452 U. S. 576. The Department of Justice's 1981 guidelines on RICO prosecutions are also unpersuasive
column13: since 1984 amendments broadened the focus of RICO prosecutions from those association-in-fact enterprises that exist ""for the purpose of maintaining operations directed toward an economic goal"" to those that are ""directed toward an economic or other identifiable goal."" In addition
column15: and there is no clearly expressed intent to the contrary in the legislative history that would warrant a different construction. Nor is there an ambiguity in RICO that would suffice to invoke the rule of lenity. See Sedima
column16: S. P. R. L. v. Imrex Co.

ABF FREIGHT SYSTEM
column2: INC. v. NATIONAL LABOR RELATIONS BOARD

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE TENTH CIRCUIT
No. 92-1550. Argued December 1
Mter Michael Manso gave his employer
column3: Inc. (ABF)
column4: a false excuse for being late to work
column5: ABF ascertained that he was lying and fired him on the asserted ground of tardiness. He filed an unfair labor practice charge with the National Labor Relations Board (Board) and repeated his false tardiness excuse while testifying under oath before an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ)
column6: who denied him relief upon concluding that he had lied and that ABF had discharged him for cause. The Board reversed in relevant part
column7: finding that ABF did not in fact fire Manso for lying but had seized upon his tardiness as a pretext to discharge him for earlier union activities. Notwithstanding his dishonesty
column8: the Board ordered ABF to reinstate him with backpay. The Court of Appeals enforced the order
column9: rejecting ABF's argument that awarding reinstatement and backpay to an employee who lied to his employer and to the ALJ violated public policy.

column1: Held: Manso's false testimony under oath before the ALJ did not preclude the Board from granting him reinstatement with backpay. Although such misconduct is intolerable in a formal proceeding
column2: 29 U. S. C.  160(c) expressly delegates to the Board the primary responsibility for making remedial decisions
column3: including awarding reinstatement with backpay
column4: that best effectuate the policies of the National Labor Relations Act (Act) when the Board has substantiated an unfair labor practice. Confronted with that kind of express delegation
column5: courts must give an agency's decision controlling weight unless it is arbitrary
column6: capricious
column7: or manifestly contrary to the Act. It cannot be said that the Board's remedial order in this case was an abuse of its broad discretion or that it was obligated to adopt a rigid rule that would foreclose relief in all comparable cases. Nor can its conclusions be faulted that Manso's reason for being late to work was ultimately irrelevant to whether antiunion animus actually motivated his discharge and that ordering effective relief in a case of this character promotes a vital public interest. It would be unfair to sanction Manso while indirectly rewarding the lack of candor of several ABF witnesses
column8: whose testimony the ALJ and the Board refused to credit. Moreover
column9: a categorical rule against relief might force the

column1: Board to divert its attention away from its primary mission and toward resolving collateral credibility disputes. Pp. 322-325.

column3: ET AL.

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE NINTH CIRCUIT
No. 92-74. Argued November 8
The Railroad Revitalization and Regulatory Reform Act of 1976
column3: forbids States to impose (1) higher property tax rates and assessment ratios upon ""rail transportation property"" than upon ""other commercial and industrial property
column5: and (2) ""another tax that discriminates against a rail carrier providing transportation
column6: 11503(b)(4). Oregon exempts from its ad valorem property tax various classes of business personal property
column7: but not railroad cars owned by respondent companies. They filed suit in the District Court
column8: alleging that the tax violates  11503(b)(4) because it exempts certain classes of commercial property from taxation while taxing railroad cars in full. Both the District Court and the Court of Appeals agreed that discriminatory property tax exemptions may be challenged under subsection (b)(4). However
column9: the Court of Appeals reversed the lower court's finding that Oregon's tax complied with the provision
column10: holding instead that respondents were entitled to the same exemption enjoyed by preferred property owners.

column1: Held: Section 11503 does not limit the States' discretion to exempt nonrailroad property
column3: from generally applicable ad valorem property taxes. Pp. 338-348.

column1: (a) Respondents' position that ""another tax that discriminates against a rail carrier"" is a residual category designed to reach any discriminatory state tax
column3: not covered by subsections (b)(1)-(3) is plausible only if subsection (b)(4) is read in isolation. However
column4: the structure of  11503 as a whole supports the view that subsection (b)(4) does not speak to property tax exemptions. ""[C]ommercial and industrial property
column5: which serves as the comparison class for measuring property tax discrimination under subsections (b)(1)-(3)
column6: is defined in subsection (a)(4) as ""property
column7: other than transportation property and land used primarily for agricultural purposes or timber growing
column8: devoted to commercial or industrial use and subject to a property tax levy."" The interplay between subsections (b)(1)-(3) and this definition is central to subsection (b)(4)'s interpretation. For example
column9: Congress' exclusion of agricultural land from the definition demonstrates its intent to permit the States to tax railroad property at a higher rate than agricultural land

column1: general prohibition of rate discrimination. To consider such a tax ""another tax"" under subsection (b)(4) would subvert the statutory plan by reading subsection (b)(4) to prohibit what subsection (b)(3)
column3: was designed to allow. The result would contravene the elementary canon of construction that a statute should be interpreted so as not to render one part inoperative. Pp. 338-341.

column1: (b) The phrase ""subject to a property tax levy"" further qualifies the subsection (a)(4) definition. When used elsewhere in  11503
column2: that phrase means property that is taxed; and since identical words used in different parts of the same Act are intended to have the same meaning
column3: the phrase must carry the same meaning in subsection (a)(4)
column6: 860. Thus
column7: exempt property is not part of the comparison class. It would be illogical to conclude that Congress
column8: having allowed States to grant property tax exemptions in subsections (b)(1)-(3)
column9: would turn around and nullify its own choice in subsection (b)(4). Pp. 341-343.

column1: (c) Other considerations reinforce the foregoing construction of the statute. Section 11503's silence on the subject of tax exemptions-in light of the explicit prohibition of tax rate and assessment ratio discrimination-reflects a determination to permit the States to leave their exemptions in place. Principles of federalism compel this view
column2: for a statute is interpreted to pre-empt traditional state powers only if that result is the clear and manifest purpose of Congress. The statute's legislative history casts no doubt upon this interpretation. Nor does the interpretation lead to an anomalous result. Since railroads are not the only commercial entities subject to Oregon's tax
column3: it need not be decided whether subsection (b)(4) would prohibit a tax that did single out railroad property. And since it is within Congress' sound discretion to weigh the benefit of preserving some exemptions against the benefit of protecting rail carriers from every tax scheme that favors some nonrailroad property
column4: the result reached here is not so bizarre that Congress could not have intended it. See Demarest v. Manspeaker
